lessonTitle: The Boundary as Ontological Act: From Distinction to Civilization

questions.question: What three irreducible poles of reality are created by the act of abstraction?
questions.correct_answer: The Observed (that which finds itself on this side of the boundary), the Observer (the one for whom this distinction is drawn), and the Non-observed or Nothing (the fundamental background from which the boundary is drawn).

questions.question: According to the lesson, what is the deontological imperative?
questions.correct_answer: The prohibition on initiating violence, that is, on violating the boundary of subjectivity drawn by another. It is not a moral postulate but an immanent condition for the survival of a complex system.

questions.question: What are the six quantum levels of civilization mentioned in the lesson?
questions.correct_answer: Family, Kinship/Clan, Tribe, Nation, Religion, and Civil Society.

questions.question: What do the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse represent in this philosophical reading?
questions.correct_answer: They represent systemic forces unleashed when internal boundaries are destroyed: White Horse (erases local boundaries), Red Horse (war within society), Black Horse (violation of just distribution), and Pale Horse (destruction of ecological equilibrium).

questions.question: What is the starting point before the act of abstraction occurs?
questions.correct_answer: A pre-reflective state of undifferentiated Being - not chaos, but wholeness where there is neither subject nor object, nor 'something.'
